No. 92 Weijin Road, Nankai District Tianjin 300072 China Aiming at examining the effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms over bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on the catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification of methacrolein with methanol to methyl methacrylate. Here, two kinds of surface composition with different coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms on Au modulated Pd (AuPd) and Pd modulated Au (PdAu) catalysts have been designed and employed to investigate direct oxidative esterification using density functional theory calculation. The results showed that Pd modulated Au catalysts with higher coverage of modulated Pd atoms in the presence of pre-adsorbed O exhibited higher stability for resistance toward deactivation induced by H2O deposition than Au modulated Pd and pure Au(Pd) catalysts. The formation of CH3O species mainly came from pre-adsorbed O assisted CH3OH activation rather than the direct breakage of CH3OH via O-H bond, and it was more advantageous than the activation of CH3OH via C-H bond with and without pre-adsorbed O. Additionally, Pd modulated Au catalysts with higher coverage of modulated Pd atoms improved the activity for MMA formation via MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+(H)+CH3O+*→MMA than Au modulated Pd and pure Au(Pd) catalysts. Moreover, the better catalytic performance (stability and activity) for direct oxidation esterification of Pd modulated Au catalysts with higher coverage of modulated Pd atoms were attributed to less average charge of surfaces atoms and the d-band center close to the Fermi level compared with pure Au(Pd) and Au modulated Pd catalysts. Therefore, it is proposed that Pd modulated Au catalysts are promising for direct oxidative esterification reaction of methacrolein with methanol to methyl methacrylate. This study not only helps understanding theory on direct oxidative esterification mechanism on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts, but also provides clues for the design of high-effectively bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts for direct oxidative esterification. Graphical adstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts Coverage Direct oxidative esterification Methyl methacrylate Density functional theory 1 Introduction As an important industrial chemical raw materials, methyl methacrylate (MMA) has been widely studied in the production of polymer dispersions for acrylic plastics and other coatings [1–3]. The traditional methods for the synthesis of MMA include acetone cyanohydrin (ACH) and isobutene (IB) oxidation, which not only require multistep process, but also corrode the equipment and produce a large number of by-products [4,5]. Recently, a green and sustainable production route for the synthesis of MMA by direct oxidative esterification of methacrolein (MAL) with methanol (CH3OH) in the presence of molecular oxygen (O2) has been discovered and investigated [6–8]. Direct oxidative esterification has been reported on Pd-based catalysts, but the selectivity of MMA was lower because Pd was easy to be oxidized [9–14]. In addition, it was generally recognized that MMA formation via dehydrogenation of MAL following coupling with CH3O group in the process of direct oxidative esterification of MAL to MMA on Pd-based catalysts [15,16]. Au-based catalysts have attracted more and more attention in heterogeneous catalytic reaction [18–30]. Marsden et al. [27] reported that supported Au catalysts have high yield of methyl acrylate in aerobic oxidation of aldehydes. Casanova et al. [29] investigated the oxidative esterification of 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural into 2, 5-dimethylfuroate on Au/CeO2 catalysts, in which the alcohol oxidation to aldehyde was the rate-limiting step of the reaction. Ke et al. [30] confirmed that the catalytic activity of supported Au catalysts depended on the diameter of Au particle. However, these Au-based catalysts are affected by instability duo to the Au aggregation in the reaction process [26]. Therefore, it is still a challenge to regulated Pd-based and Au-based catalysts with high catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification reaction. Nowadays, bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts have received increasing attention because of the electronic and geometric effects between Au and Pd atoms. It is well known that bimetallic Pd-Au system mainly concentrated on the Au-doped Pd catalysts and Pd-doped Au catalysts. For example, Enache et al. [31] showed that the addition of Pd to Au for the formation of PdAu catalysts increased the oxidation activity of alcohol and the selectivity for the formation of aldehyde. Pritchard et al. [32] observed that the catalytic performance for direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide and benzyl alcohol oxidation on AuPd catalysts with optimum ratio of Au and Pd (1:1.85) gradually improved. A more detailed study about the effect of thermal treatment on the surface composition and catalytic activity of Pd-Au catalysts was also reported [33]. Yang et al. [34] studied the diffusion mechanism of metal atoms in bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts under CO atmosphere using molecular dynamic. Xu et al. [35] reported CO oxidation on a compositional series of Pd-Au supported on SiO2 catalysts, and confirmed that Pd-Au alloy catalysts showed significant activity and stability toward low-temperature CO oxidation. In addition, bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts have also been widely applied in the decomposition of HCOOH, showing higher catalytic activity for the activation of HCOOH [36–40]. A large number of experiments have pointed to the fact that the catalytic performance for heterogeneous reactions of bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts depended on the ratio of Au and Pd on the surface of the catalysts, namely, the catalytic performance for heterogeneous reactions of bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts is particularly sensitive to the surface coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms. However, as far as we know, direct oxidative esterification mechanism on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts has not been mentioned. Therefore, up to now, due to the lack of incomplete information, the fundamental understanding on the effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms over bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on the stability of Pd-Au catalysts and catalytic performance for direct oxidation esterification are still not unclear. This work is designed to solve above issues based on density functional theory methods, the effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms over bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on H2O activation, CH3OH activation and the formation of MMA would be systematically investigated, which are also as probe for insight into the catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification of bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts including Au modulated Pd and Pd modulated Au catalysts. Meanwhile, the electronic properties of bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts with different coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms are carried out to obtain a deeper understanding the effect of surface composition. Further, the effect of coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification would be confirmed. This study is of great significance for designing and optimizing bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts with higher stability and catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification reaction. 2 Computational details 2.1 Computational methods DFT calculations were performed using Dmol3 program package of Materials Studio 8.0 [41,42]. GGA-PBE functional was used to presented the exchanged correlation effect [43,44]. The valence electron function was carried out by DNP [45,46]. All electron basis set was treated for small molecules, and effective core potential was used for the inner electrons of Pd and Au atoms [47,48], and a smearing of 0.001 Ha was applied for all the calculations. A 4 × 4 × 1 k-points was selected to the surface and bulk alloy, which was found to be accurate and efficient for calculations. For an elementary step, complete LST/QST techniques were used for locating the transition-state structure. Further, frequency analysis with only one imaginary frequency confirmed the transition state [49,50], which not only confirmed the transition state, but also given out the zero-point energy correction, thermal energy and entropy at a given temperature. In addition, TS confirmation could verify the transition state (TS) connected directly from initial state (IS) to final state (FS). The adsorption energy of the species involving in producing MMA from MAL by oxidative esterification reaction on Pd-based and Au-based catalysts were obtained using Eq. (1): (1) E ads = E species + E slab − E slab / species E species and E slab were the total energy of the free adsorbate and bare Pd-based and Au-based catalysts surface directly obtained from DFT calculations, respectively. E slab/species was the total energy of optimized adsorbate-surface system obtained from DFT calculations. For a elementary reaction, activation energy (E a) and reaction energy (ΔE) were calculated by Eqs. (2) and (3): (2) E a = E TS − E IS (3) Δ E = E FS − E IS E IS, E TS and E FS were the total energies of reactant, transition state and final state directly from DFT calculation, respectively. Gibbs free energy corrections correlated to zero-point energy, thermal energy and entropy at different temperature were obtained by frequency analysis. Since the direct oxidative esterification proceeded from 300 to 400 K [7,9–12], correspondingly, adsorption free energy, activation free energy and reaction free energy according to harmonic Transition State Theory (TST) [51] in this work were given out at 350K. The adsorption free energy (G ads) was obtained based on the following Eq. (4) at 350 K. (4) G a d s = E a d s o r b a t e + E s l a b − − E t o t a l + G a d s o r b a t e + G s l a b − − G t o t a l G adsorbate, G slab and G total referred to Gibbs free energy corrections. With this definition, the more positive G ads is, the stronger the adsorption is. Activation free energy (Ga ) and reaction free energy (∆G) were estimated on the basis of the Eqs. (5) and (6) at 350 K. (5) G a = E T S − E I S + G T S − G I S (6) Δ G = E F S − E I S + G F S − G I S G IS, G TS and G FS were the corresponding Gibbs free energy correction at 350 K obtained from the output document of frequency analysis in DMol3 module. Reaction rate constants (k) for a reaction process can be obtained using harmonic Transition State Theory (TST) by Eqs. (7) and (8) [51]: (7) k = k B T h q T s q I S exp ( − G a k B T ) (8) q = 1 ∏ i = 1 V i b r a t i o n 1 − exp ( − h v i k B T ) q was partition function calculated based on Eq. (8), vi was the vibrational frequency. 2.2 Computational model For pure Pd and Au catalysts, it is well known that the main exposed surface is the (111) surface, which is also most stable surface [52–54]. As a result, p(2 × 2) Pd(111) and Au(111) with three layers were applied to model Pd and Au catalysts, which were cleaved from the optimized lattice parameters of 3.954 and 4.077 Å, which were close to the experimental values of 3.891 and 4.078 Å [55]. During the calculations, the bottom one layer was fixed; both the adsorbed species and the topmost two layers were allowed to relax completely. 15 Å vacuum slab was set to avoid the interactions between the slabs for surfaces and bulk atoms. Furthermore, for Au modulated Pd catalysts (AuPd), in order to present the effect of different coverage of modulated Au atoms, the topmost Pd atoms of Pd(111) were replaced by Au atoms with the replaced numbers of 1, 2, 3, 4 and 16, the corresponding coverage of modulated Au atoms were 1/16, 1/8, 3/16, 1/4 and 1 ML, which were named as Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111), Au4Pd(111) and AuMLPd(111). Similarly, for Pd modulated Au catalysts (PdAu) were also constructed by replacing the topmost Au atoms of Au(111) using Pd atoms, the replaced numbers were 1, 2, 3, 4 and 16, the corresponding coverage of modulated Pd atoms were 1/16, 1/8, 3/16, 1/4 and 1 ML, thus, these models were named as Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111), Pd3Au(111), Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111). The optimized structures and the corresponding active sites of Au modulated Pd (AuPd) and Pd modulated Au (PdAu) catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 (a)–(l). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Possible reaction mechanism for direct oxidative esterification of MAL with CH3OH into MMA As shown in Scheme 1, the possible reaction mechanism for direct oxidation esterification of MAL with CH3OH in the presence of O2 on Pd-based and Au-based catalysts were summarized based on previous experimental and computational investigations in detail [9–11,15–17]. Direct oxidation esterification was H2O-containing system, resulting in the decrease of the stability of the catalysts because of deactivation by the formed water film. The direct dissociation of H2O is very difficult to occur. However, previous studies [17] showed that pre-adsorbed O from O2 molecule not only changed the activation pathway of H2O but also promoted the activation of H2O. Thus, pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation (O+H2O+*→2OH) was firstly considered and examined to confirm the effect of the coverage of modulated Au and Pd atoms on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on the stability of resistance toward deactivation induced by H2O. MAL and CH3OH as reactants, their conversion are the first step, among, MAL is activated into acyl group (CH2C(CH3)CO) and H (MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H), and CH3OH is converted into methoxy (CH3O) and H (CH3OH+*→CH3O+H). MMA as products, three formation pathways in the presence of surface adsorbed MAL, CH2C(CH3)CO, CH3O and H are summarized, Path 1: MAL + * →CH2C(CH3)CO + (H) + CH3O + * → MMA, Path 2: MAL + CH3O + * → CH2C(CH3)CHOOCH3 + * → MMA + H and Path 3: CH2C(CH3)CHOOCH3+ H + * → CH2C(CH3)CHOHOCH3 + * → CH2C(CH3)COHOCH3 + H + * → MMA + H. Previous direct oxidation esterification mechanism [15,16] showed that MMA formation via Path 1 was more advantageous compared with Path 2 and Path 3. Thus, MMA formation along the attack of CH3O into CH2C(CH3)CO was calculated to study the effect of the coverage of modulated Au and Pd atoms on the catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification of bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts. On the basis of above analysis, if the bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts could promote pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation, CH3OH activation and MMA formation, the stability of resistance toward deactivation of bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts would be improved, and the catalytic activity for MMA formation of bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts would also be enhanced. As a result, the catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification of bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts can be improved. Therefore, above mentioned reactions were carried out on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts to understand the effect of the coverage of modulated Au and Pd atoms on catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification. Activation free energies, reaction free energies, the corresponding only imaginary frequency and the reaction rate constant involved in pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation, CH3OH activation, MMA formation on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts are shown in Table 1 . 3.2 Adsorption of all possible species in direct oxidation esterification 3.2.1 The stale adsorption configuration of key species Table 2 presented the key structural parameters and adsorption free energies of the most stable configurations involved in direct oxidative esterification on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts, the corresponding stable adsorption configurations were shown in Fig. 2 . 3.2.2 The charge density difference analysis of MAL adsorbed on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts MAL was key species for direct oxidative esterification of MAL into MMA, its adsorption was firstly investigated, and the interaction between MAL and bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts was studied by adsorption free energy. Moreover, charge density difference of MAL adsorbed on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts was calculated to confirm the adsorption free energy, as shown in Fig. 3 . For Au modulated Pd catalysts (see Fig. 3(a)–(f)), with the increasing coverage of modulated Pd, weaker interactions are presented, the corresponding adsorption free energies on Pd(111), Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111), Au4Pd(111) and AuMLPd(111) are 63.6, 87.1, 88.9, 48.8, 46.1 and 44.3 kJ•mol−1. However, the interaction between MAL and Pd modulated Au catalysts (see Fig. 3(g)–(l)) are enhanced with the increasing coverage of modulated Au atoms, the corresponding adsorption free energies on Au(111), Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111), Pd3Au(111), Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) are 45.3, 46.8, 46.3, 72.9, 80.0 and 118.5 kJ•mol−1. Namely, the adsorption ability of MAL on Pd modulated Au catalysts with the increasing coverage of modulated Pd have a stronger trend than that of MAL on Au modulated Pd catalysts with the increasing coverage of modulated Au, and more MAL can sufficiently adsorb on PdnAu(111) (n=1, 2, 3, 4 and 16) with the increasing coverage of modulated Pd, then, subsequently participate in direct oxidation esterification reaction. Moreover, the charge density difference is presented to investigate the specific interaction, red region represents electron enrichment, and blue region represents electron depletion. For Au modulated Pd catalysts, MAL has an obvious electronic interaction with Pd(111) compared with AunPd(111) (n=1, 2, 3, 4 and 16). For Pd modulated Au catalysts, MAL has more obvious electronic interaction with PdnAu(111) surfaces (n=1, 2, 3, 4 and 16) compared with Au(111), resulting in more MAL adsorbed on Pd modulated Au catalysts with the increasing coverage of modulated Pd, which may exhibit better catalytic performance for direct oxidation esterification, which can also help to form more MMA. Xiao et al. [56] confirmed the interaction between Pt and Al atoms by charge density difference analysis. 3.2.3 The charge density difference analysis of MMA adsorbed on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts MMA as the objective product in direct oxidative esterification of MAL into MMA, its adsorption property including adsorption free energies and charge density difference were also carried out, as shown in Fig. 4 . For Au modulated Pd catalysts (see Fig. 4(a)–(f)), Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111), Au4Pd(111) and AuMLPd(111) improve the adsorption ability of MMA compared to Pd(111) (88.2, 86.8, 67.5, 55.3, 56.2 vs. 49.6 kJ•mol−1). For Pd modulated Au catalysts (see Fig. 4(g)–(l)), Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111), Pd3Au(111), Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) with the increasing coverage of modulated Au atoms greatly promote MMA adsorption than Au(111), the corresponding adsorption free energy is 57.1, 63.1, 69.6, 77.7, 107.6 and 54.5 kJ•mol−1. In addition, it can be seen from charge density difference that more electron enrichment between MMA and AunPd (111) and PdnAu(111) (n=1, 2, 3, 4 and 16) compared with pure Pd(111) and Au(111). Based on above analysis, MMA on PdAu catalysts has stronger adsorption ability than on AuPd catalysts, PdnAu(111) (n=1, 2, 3, 4 and 16) can be sufficient for MMA adsorption in direct oxidation esterification. Bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts may exhibit poor catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification duo to the weaker adsorption of MMA. 3.3 Activation of H2O assisted by pre-adsorbed O In the experiment, MMA have been investigated via direct oxidative esterification MAL with CH3OH in the presence of excessive O2, it can be considered that the pre-adsorbed O. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), the activation free energy of O2 dissociation into two O atoms on Pd(111) and Au(111) were 101.8 and 143.8 kJ•mol−1. Further, the diffusion free energy of O atom on Pd(111) and Au(111) were calculated, as shown in Fig. 5(b), the results showed that the surface O atom easily occur migration and diffusion with lower diffusion free energy of 38.7 and 35.1 kJ•mol−1, indicating that the formation of pre-adsorbed O can easily occur from O2 dissociation and O atom diffusion on Pd and Au catalysts, which are consistent with experimental phenomenon that charging excessive O2 in direct oxidation esterification system. In addition, as shown in Fig. 5(c), the direct dissociation of H2O on Pd(111) and Au(111) need higher activation free energy (165.7 and 198.6 kJ•mol−1), thus, the product H2O can cause aggregation, and the stability of resistance deactivation induced by H2O of the catalysts would be weaken. Based on above analysis, authors think that the pre-adsorbed O exist on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts due to the excessive O2 atmosphere of direct oxidation esterification and the higher adsorption free energy of O atom. However, more studies showed that co-adsorbed intermediate could regulate the catalytic performance [57]. In this study, the role of pre-adsorbed O on H2O activation on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts is investigated. If activation free energy of pre-adsorbed O assisted activation of H2O (O+H2O+*→2OH) decreased on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts, bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts can improve the stability of resistance toward deactivation induced by H2O deposition. The free energy profile of pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation with related structures on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts are presented in Fig. 6 (a)–(c). As shown in Fig. 6(b), for Au modulated Pd catalysts, Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111) and Au4Pd(111) with the coverage of Au atoms of 1/16, 1/8, 3/16 and 1/4 ML greatly promote the pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation with lower activation free energies of 49.3, 30.6, 5.7 and 13.5 kJ•mol−1 compared with pure Pd(111) (62.4 kJ•mol−1), especially for Au3Pd(111) and Au4Pd(111), the corresponding reaction rate constants on Pd(111), Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111) and Au4Pd(111) are 4.66 × 103, 2.74 × 105, 2.55 × 108, 1.01 × 1012 and 2.23 × 1013 s −1. Moreover, it is exothermic on Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111) and Au4Pd(111) compared with Au1Pd(111) and Pd(111), suggesting that the 1/8, 3/16 and 1/4 ML of Au atoms on AuPd catalysts are favorable for pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation both kinetically and thermodynamically. However, AuMLPd(111) with the 1 ML of Au atom needs to overcome higher activation free energy of 125.7 kJ•mol−1, the reaction rate constant is 7.16 × 10−7 s −1, indicating that higher coverage of Au atoms on AuPd catalysts suppress H2O activation via pre-adsorbed O assisted pathway, while it is smaller than the direct dissociation of H2O on Pd(111) and Au(111) (165.7 and 198.6 kJ•mol−1). Compared to pure Au(111), for Pd modulated Au catalysts, further calculated results show that whether it is the 1/16, 1/8, 3/16 and 1/4 ML or 1 ML of Pd atoms on PdAu catalysts, all greatly decrease the activation free energies of H2O activation via O+H2O+*→2OH, especially for Au3Pd(111) and Au4Pd(111), the activation free energies on Au(111), Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111), Pd3Au(111), Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) are 43.4, 25.3, 15.2, 7.8, 8.0 and 28.3 kJ•mol−1, the corresponding reaction rate constants are 2.28 × 106, 2.50 × 1011, 5.93 × 1010, 1.23 × 109, 4.15 × 1011 and 1.06 × 1011 s −1. On the whole, bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts with the presence of pre-adsorbed O are beneficial of the activation of H2O, enhance the reaction rate constants of the pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation, suppress the formation of H2O film, further the stability of bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts resistance toward deactivation induced by H2O deposition are improved, which is beneficial to facilitating the following direct oxidative esterification reaction. The improved stability of bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts can attribute to the pre-adsorbed O and surface structure and surface composition. Previous study by Zhang et al. [57] showed that the surface adsorbed CH, CH2 and CH3 intermediates not only participated in the reaction with CO or CHO as the reactive intermediate, but also facilitated CO activation as a self-promoter, which all were in favor of CO activation and conversion to form C2 oxygenates. Moreover, a lot of studies [58–61] confirmed that the surface structure and surface composition of the pure and bimetallic Co-, Pd- and Cu-based catalysts have impacts on carbon chain growth in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, HCOOH decomposition and the hydrogenation of C2H2. 3.4 Activation mechanism of CH3OH: CH3O species formation When CH3OH adsorbs on the surface of catalysts, active sites promote adsorbed CH3OH activation, and the activated product of CH3OH would participate in the next step of direct oxidation esterification. Thus, the activation of CH3OH as the first and key step in direct oxidative esterification process is worth studying. In this work, activation mechanism of CH3OH with and without prep-adsorbed O was considered, further the effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on the activation of CH3OH can be confirmed. 3.4.1 Activating O-H bond of CH3OH into CH3O and H on clean bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts The free energy profile of the activation of CH3OH via O-H bond with related structures on bimetallic Au-Pd catalysts were presented in Fig. 7 . As shown in Fig. 7(b), obviously, with the increasing coverage of 1/16, 1/8, 3/16, 1/4 and 1 ML of Au atoms modulated Pd catalysts not only do not promote the direct dissociation of CH3OH via O-H bond, but also inhibit its activation with higher activation free energies (199.1, 231.1, 252.3, 225.8, 389.3 kJ•mol−1) compared with pure Pd(111) (144.9 kJ•mol−1), the corresponding reaction rate constants on Pd(111), Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111), Au4Pd(111) and AuMLPd(111) are 7.31 × 10−2, 1.63 × 10−16, 0.10 × 10−19, 4.74 × 10−27, 1.32 × 10−21 and 1.30 × 10−44 s −1. For Pd modulated Au catalysts (see Fig. 7(b)), Pd1Au(111) and Pd2Au(111) with 1/16 and 1/8 ML of Au atoms have similar activation free energies (200.4 and 201.7 kJ•mol−1) compared with pure Au(111) (203.0 kJ•mol−1). Pd3Au(111), Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) with 3/16, 1/4 and 1 ML of Au atoms decrease the activation free energies (188.2, 183.9 and 162.5 kJ•mol−1), suggesting that higher coverage of modulated Pd atoms on Au catalysts are in favor of the direct dissociation of CH3OH via O-H bond, the corresponding reaction rate constants on Au(111), Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111), Pd3Au(111), Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) are 2.75 × 10−20, 9.28 × 10−18, 2.12 × 10−15, 1.24 × 10−20, 4.65 × 10−17 and 5.01 × 10−12 s −1. However, compared with Pd(111), PdMLAu(111) with 1 ML of modulated Au atoms cannot promote the direct dissociation of CH3OH via O-H bond because of higher activation free energy (144.9 vs. 162.5 kJ•mol−1). Generally speaking, Pd modulated Au catalysts are beneficial to the direct activation of CH3OH compared with Au modulated Pd catalysts. Considering the direct oxidative esterification process of MAL to MMA is in oxygen atmosphere, therefore, the pre-adsorbed O assisted activation of CH3OH as well as the direct dissociation of CH3OH via O-H bond are calculated in the following discussion, Pd(111), Au1Pd(111), Au(111) and Pd4Au (111) are chosen as the representative surfaces. 3.4.2 Activating O-H and C-H bonds of CH3OH on clean and pre-adsorbed O bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts In order to further confirm the role of pre-adsorbed O on the activation of CH3OH, pre-adsorbed O assisted activation of CH3OH via O-H bond (CH3OH+O+*→CH3O+OH) on Pd(111), Au1Pd(111), Au(111) and Pd4Au(111) were firstly considered, and the activation of CH3OH via C-H bond with and without pre-adsorbed O (CH3OH+*→CH2OH+H and CH3OH+O+*→CH2OH+OH) were also calculated, the corresponding only imaginary frequency activation free energies, reaction free energies and the reaction rate constant were shown in Table 3 , the free energy profile of selective oxidation of CH3OH with related structures was shown in Fig. 8 . As shown in Fig. 8, the activation of CH3OH via O-H bond with and without pre-adsorbed O need to overcome higher activation free energy (pink and blue lines), indicating that the activation of CH3OH via O-H bond breakage is not favor. Further, comparing the activation of CH3OH via O-H with and without pre-adsorbed O on Pd(111), Au1Pd(111), Au(111) and Pd4Au(111), resulting in the formation of CH3O, it can be found that CH3OH+O+*→CH3O+OH is the most favorable activation path of the activation CH3OH with lower activation free energy of 28.1, 22.0, 43.1 and 20.3 kJ•mol−1, the corresponding reaction rate constant are 4.62 × 109, 7.78 × 1012, 5.46 × 106 and 3.47 × 1013 s −1. Moreover, the activation free energy difference between CH3OH+*→CH3O+H and CH3OH+O+*→CH3O+OH represents the ability of producing CH3O on Pd(111), Au1Pd(111), Au(111) and Pd4Au(111), the corresponding activation free energy difference are 116.8, 177.1, 159.9 and 163.6 kJ•mol−1, respectively. It is confirmed that pre-adsorbed O assisted path (CH3OH+O+*→CH3O+OH) is the CH3O group source rather than the direct dissociation path (CH3OH+*→CH3O+H), and the sequence for producing CH3O is Au1Pd(111)> Pd4Au(111)>Au(111)>Pd(111). Therefore, the activation of CH3OH via O-H bond in the presence of pre-adsorbed O should be especially favorable for CH3O species formation rather than the direct dissociation of CH3OH via O-H bond, the calculated results are consistent with previous reports [62,63]. 3.5 Reaction pathway for MMA formation on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA was calculated to confirm the effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on the activity for MMA formation. Reaction pathway, the free energy profile of MMA formation via MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA with related structures on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts were presented in Figs. 9 (a)–(c) and 10 (a)–(c). 3.5.1 Formation of MMA on Au modulated Pd catalysts As shown in Fig. 9(b), MMA formation via MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA on AuPd catalysts was firstly analyzed, the rate-controlled step on Pd(111) is CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA with activation free energy of 123.3 kJ•mol−1, the reaction rate constant is 1.77 × 10−6 s −1. However, compared with Pd(111), Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111), Au4Pd(111) and AuMLPd(111) change the rate-controlled step (MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H) with higher activation free energy of 158.4, 181.5, 175.6, 171.8 and 188.4 kJ•mol−1, the corresponding reaction rate constant are 1.42 × 10−10, 6.82 × 10−14, 8.17 × 10−14, 3.31 × 10−14 and 5.46 × 10−16 s −1. In addition, the overall activation free energy barrier for MMA formation via MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA on Pd(111), Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111), Au4Pd(111) and AuMLPd(111) are 105.9, 158.4, 202.4, 175.6, 210.0 and 259.0 kJ•mol−1, respectively, proving that Au modulated Pd catalysts suppress MMA formation. Thus, Au modulated Pd catalysts with the increasing coverage of modulated Au atoms from 1/16, 1/8, 3/16, 1/4 to 1 ML cannot improve the activity for direct oxidative esterification reaction. 3.5.2 Formation of MMA on Pd modulated Au catalysts As shown in Fig. 10(b), the rate-controlled step for MMA formation via MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA on Au(111), Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111) and Pd3Au(111) with 0, 1/16, 1/8 and 3/16 ML of Pd atoms is MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H. Compared with Au(111), Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111) and Pd3Au(111) with 1/16, 1/8 and 3/16 ML of Pd atoms reduce the activation free energy for the rate-controlled step (164.7 vs.136.9, 127.4, 115.7 kJ•mol−1), the reaction rate constants for MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H on Au(111), Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111) and Pd3Au(111) are 1.82 × 10−13, 3.18 × 10−6, 8.80 × 10−8 and 1.29 × 10−10 s −1. However, Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) with 1/4 and 1 ML of Pd atoms not only change the rate-controlled step (CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA) compared with Au(111), but also the corresponding activation free energy is lower (96.6, 109.0 vs. 164.7 kJ•mol−1), the reaction rate constants for CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA on Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) are 3.74 × 10−3 and 2.57 × 10−1 s −1. On the other hand, compared with pure Au(111), the needed overall activation free energy barrier on Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111), Pd3Au(111) Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) with the increasing coverage of modulated Pd atoms from 1/16, 1/8, 3/16, 1/4 to 1 ML is smaller (164.7 vs. 164.1, 144.9, 144.4, 100.5, 115.1 kJ•mol−1). Compared with the overall activation free energy barrier for MMA formation on Pd modulated Au catalysts that Pd(111), Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111), Au4Pd(111) and AuMLPd(111) (105.9, 158.4, 202.4, 175.6, 210.0 and 259.0 kJ•mol−1), Au(111) Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111), Pd3Au(111) Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111), Au modulated Pd catalysts that Au(111), Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111), Pd3Au(111) Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) with the increasing coverage of modulated Au atoms not only change the rate-controlled step, but also reduce the overall activation free energy barrier of 164.7, 164.1, 144.9, 144.4, 100.5 and 115.1 kJ•mol−1. Therefore, Au modulated Pd catalysts with higher coverage of modulated Pd atoms exhibit better activity for MMA formation via MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA due to the synergistic effect between Au and Pd atoms than puer Pd, Pd modulated Au and pure Au catalysts. 3.6 Effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atom on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification To better understand the effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification of MAL with CH3OH to MMA, the activation free energy difference including pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation (O+H2O+*→2OH), CH3OH activation (CH3OH+*→CH3O+H), the rate-controlled step for MMA formation via MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA and the overall activation energy barrier in the path of MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA on Au modulated Pd (AuPd) and Pd modulated Au (PdAu) compared with pure Pd and Au are used to quantify the effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms, which are also used as a descriptor, that is, the more negative the activation free energy difference is, the more favorable the reaction is, and the better catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification of the catalysts is. For Au modulated Pd (AuPd), compared to pure Pd, as shown in Fig. 11 (a), activation free energy difference values for pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation on Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111) and Au4Pd(111) with 1/16, 1/8, 3/16 and 1/4 ML of modulated Au atoms are negative (-13.1, -31.8, -56.7 and -48.9 kJ•mol−1), suggesting that introduced Au atoms on AuPd catalysts promote pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation, and further improve the ability of resistance toward deactivation induced by H2O film formation. However, the other activation free energy difference values are all positive values. Obviously, it can be concluded that the modulated Au atoms on AuPd catalysts with 1/16, 1/8, 3/16 and 1/4 ML enhance the stability of AuPd catalysts, however, CH3OH activation via CH3OH+*→CH3O+H, the rate-controlled step for MMA formation and the overall activation free energy for MMA formation via MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA are generally inhibited with the increasing coverage of modulated Au atoms on Au modulated Pd catalysts. As shown in Fig. 11(b), the activation free energy difference values on Pd modulated Au catalysts (PdAu) are all negative, and they are more negative with the increasing coverage of modulated Pd atoms on Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111), Pd3Au(111), Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) for pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation (-18.1, -28.2, -35.6, -35.4 and -15.1 kJ•mol−1), CH3OH activation (-2.6, -1.3, -14.8, -19.1 and -40.5 kJ•mol−1), the rate-controlled step for MMA formation (-27.8, -37.3, -49.0, -68.1 and -55.7 kJ•mol−1), and the overall activation free energy barrier in the path of MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA (-0.6, -19.8, -20.3, -64.2 and -49.6 kJ•mol−1), suggesting that the more promoting effect for pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation, CH3OH activation and MMA formation with the increasing coverage of modulated Pd atoms on Au catalysts, especially for Pd4Au(111). Further, compared to pure Pd(111), similarly, Pd4Au(111) effectively promote pre-adsorbed O assisted H2O activation via O+H2O+*→2OH (62.4 vs. 8.0 kJ•mol−1), facilitate pre-adsorbed O assisted CH3OH activation via CH3OH+O+*→CH3O+H (28.1 vs. 20.3 kJ•mol−1), reduce activation free energy of the rate-controlled step that CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA for MMA formation (123.3 vs. 96.6 kJ•mol−1), and accelerate the MMA formation via MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA (105.9 vs. 100.5 kJ•mol−1). Therefore, DFT results can confirm that Pd modulated Au catalysts (PdAu) enhance the stability for resistance toward deactivation induced by H2O deposition, and exhibit better activity for MMA formation than pure Pd, Au modulated Pd and pure Au catalysts, further the catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification is enhanced. Moreover, Pd4Au(111) with 1/4 ML of modulated Pd atoms on Au catalysts showed best catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification. All in all, Pd modulated Au catalysts with 1/4 ML of modulated Pd atoms should be synthesized in experiment rather than Au modulated Pd (AuPd) catalysts. Our calculated results are well consistent with previous experimental results that Kesavan et al. [64] showed that supported Pd-Au nanoparticles exhibited high selectivity to benzyl benzoate under mild solvent-free conditions, and more studies were focused [25,33,65] on the preparation of bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts. 3.7 The relationship between charge and the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts The charge distribution of the surface Pd and Au atoms on Au modulated Pd (AuPd) and Pd modulated Au (PdAu) catalysts were obtained. Aiming at clarifying the effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms on the charge distribution, mulliken charge of the surface Pd and Au atoms on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts were associated with the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts. Further, the electronic effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on the catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification would be confirmed. For Au modulated Pd catalysts, as shown in Fig. 12 (a)–(c), the electrons transfer from Pd to Au atoms with the increasing coverage of modulated Au atoms (see Fig. 12(b)). Compared with pure Au, for Pd modulated Au catalysts (PdAu) (see Fig. 12(d)–(f), Au atoms get electrons from Pd with the increasing coverage of modulated Pd atoms (see Fig. 12(d)). Above results are consistent with the electronegativity that Au (2.4000) is stronger than Pd (2.2000) [66], and Au atoms are easier to get electrons than Pd atoms. In addition, the mulliken charge of the main metals Pd and Au atoms on AuPd and PdAu catalysts present a better relationship with the coverage of Pd and Au atoms (see Fig. 12(b) and (d)) than the modulated metals of Au and Pd (see Fig. 12(a) and (e)) due to the higher R2 values (0.9487, 0.9986 vs. 0.8469, 0.7278). Moreover, the average charge of the surface atoms on Pd(111), Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111), Au4Pd(111) and AuMLPd(111) are -0.0170, -0.0174, -0.0178, -0.0183, -0.0201 and -0.02000 e, they are -0.0050, -0.0044, -0.0041, -0.0038, -0.0035 and 0.0050 e on Au(111), Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111), Pd3Au(111), Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) (see Fig. 12(c) and (f)), it is worth noting that, AuPd catalysts with the increasing coverage of modulated Au atom are with more charges, resulting in poor stability for resistance towards deactivation and low activity for MMA formation in direct oxidation esterification, however, PdAu catalysts with the increasing coverage of modulated Pd atoms are with less charges, causing higher stability for resistance towards deactivation and better activity for MMA formation in direct oxidative esterification, especially for Pd4Au(111) with 1/4 ML of modulated Pd atoms have stronger catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification of MAL to MMA. Therefore, the average charge on the surface atoms is closely related to the stability for resistance towards deactivation and activity toward MMA formation in direct oxidative esterification, namely, too more average charge of surface atoms on the catalysts corresponds to low catalytic performance for MMA formation. In order to achieve high stability for resistance towards deactivation and catalytic performance for MMA formation on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts, the average charge of surface atoms should be less, the corresponding coverage of modulated atoms should be kept at a moderate value instead of too more or too less. In addition, a small amount of Pd doped into the main metal of Au catalysts forming bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts are effective for direct oxidative esterification rather than Au doped into the main metal of Pd forming bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts. 3.8 Electronic properties analysis Up to now, previous studies [67–70] showed that d­band helped understanding about bond formation and chemical reactivity in heterogeneous catalysis, and the relationship between the electronic properties of metals and their chemical reaction activity have been established. To further illustrate the effect the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms and the role of second metals Au(Pd) atoms on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts, the d-band center is calculated by Eq. (9) [71,72]. (9) ε d = ∫ − ∞ E f E ρ d ( E ) dE ∫ − ∞ E f ρ d ( E ) dE The d-band center of the surface atoms for pure Pd and Au as well as bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts were presented in Fig. 13 (a)–(l). For Au modulated Pd catalysts (AuPd), the d-band center of Au1Pd(111), Au2Pd(111), Au3Pd(111), Au4Pd(111) and AuMLPd(111) with the increasing coverage of modulated Au atoms are more away from Fermi energy level compared with pure Pd(111) (-2.05, -2.20, -2.23, -2.15, -3.52 vs. -1.99 eV), showing lower catalytic performance for MMA formation in direct oxidative esterification. However, for Pd modulated Au catalysts (PdAu), the d-band center of Pd1Au(111), Pd2Au(111), Pd3Au(111), Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) with the increasing coverage of modulated Pd atoms are close to Fermi energy level compared with Au(111) (-3.18, -3.08, -2.99, -2.94, -1.75 vs. -3.28 eV), which present better catalytic performance for MMA formation in direct oxidative esterification. Moreover, it can be found that the d-band center of Pd4Au(111) and PdMLAu(111) surfaces with 1 ML of modulated Pd atoms on Au catalysts is greatly close to Fermi energy level compared with pure Pd(111). Thus, the Pd atoms modulated Au catalysts can regulate the catalytic performance for direct oxidation esterification by changing the d-band center of the surface atoms. Generally speaking, the modulated Pd atoms on Au catalysts make the d-band center closer to Fermi energy level provide physical origin of the difference on catalytic performance for the direct oxidative esterification compared to Au modulated Pd catalysts and pure Au(Pd) catalysts causing the d-band center away from Fermi energy level, namely, the closer to the Fermi level of the d-band center of the catalysts is, the better catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification of the catalysts is. 4 Conclusion In this work, the stability for resistance towards deactivation induced by H2O and activity for MMA formation in direct oxidation esterification on Au modulated Pd (AuPd) and Pd modulated Au (PdAu) have been investigated to reveal the effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms using DFT calculations. The results illustrated that Pd modulated Au catalysts exhibited higher stability for resistance toward deactivation induced by H2O deposition via O+H2O+*→2OH than Au modulated Pd and pure Pd(Au) catalysts. Moreover, compared with pure Pd(Au) catalysts, Pd modulated Au catalysts improved the activity for MMA formation via MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+H+(CH3O)+*→MMA in direct oxidation esterification, while Au modulated Pd catalysts inhibited MMA formation. It is found that the better catalytic performance for direct oxidation esterification of Pd modulated Au catalysts with higher coverage of modulated Pd atoms is attributed to the less average charge of surface atoms and more closer to Fermi level of the d-band center, thereby it is suggested to attempt to regulate Au catalysts with Pd atoms experimentally to not only enhance the catalytic performance toward direct oxidation esterification but also reducing its usage. coredata.dc:description: Aiming at examining the effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms over bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on the catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification of methacrolein with methanol to methyl methacrylate. Here, two kinds of surface composition with different coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms on Au modulated Pd (AuPd) and Pd modulated Au (PdAu) catalysts have been designed and employed to investigate direct oxidative esterification using density functional theory calculation. The results showed that Pd modulated Au catalysts with higher coverage of modulated Pd atoms in the presence of pre-adsorbed O exhibited higher stability for resistance toward deactivation induced by H2O deposition than Au modulated Pd and pure Au(Pd) catalysts. The formation of CH3O species mainly came from pre-adsorbed O assisted CH3OH activation rather than the direct breakage of CH3OH via O-H bond, and it was more advantageous than the activation of CH3OH via C-H bond with and without pre-adsorbed O. Additionally, Pd modulated Au catalysts with higher coverage of modulated Pd atoms improved the activity for MMA formation via MAL+*→CH2C(CH3)CO+(H)+CH3O+*→MMA than Au modulated Pd and pure Au(Pd) catalysts. Moreover, the better catalytic performance (stability and activity) for direct oxidation esterification of Pd modulated Au catalysts with higher coverage of modulated Pd atoms were attributed to less average charge of surfaces atoms and the d-band center close to the Fermi level compared with pure Au(Pd) and Au modulated Pd catalysts. Therefore, it is proposed that Pd modulated Au catalysts are promising for direct oxidative esterification reaction of methacrolein with methanol to methyl methacrylate. This study not only helps understanding theory on direct oxidative esterification mechanism on bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts, but also provides clues for the design of high-effectively bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts for direct oxidative esterification.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of the coverage of modulated Au(Pd) atoms over bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts on catalytic performance for direct oxidative esterification of methacrolein into methyl methacrylate
